title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Abstract. This research project investigates the dynamic effects of the U.S. Dollar (USD) on the Australian economy, with a focus on economic stability. By employing Bayesian Structural Vector Autoregression (SVAR) analysis. This study aims to elucidate the transmission mechanisms of USD fluctuations through three channels: GDP growth, inflation, and unemployment. The findings are expected to provide nuanced insights into the macroeconomic interdependencies between the USD and the Australian economy, offering valuable perspectives for policymakers and economic analysts.
Keywords. Bayesian SVAR, USD, Australian economy, inflation, economic stability

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Likelihood
The likelihood function for the model is:
\[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) = (2\pi\lambda)^{-\frac{T}{2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Prior for \(\lambda\)
The Inverted-Gamma 2 prior for () is:
\[
p(\lambda) = \frac{(\underline{s}/2)^{\underline{\nu}/2}}{\Gamma(\underline{\nu}/2)} \lambda^{-\underline{\nu}/2-1} \exp\left(-\frac{\underline{s}}{2\lambda}\right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Prior for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\)
The Normal-Gamma-Normal (NGN) prior for (B_0) and (B_p) is assumed to be:
\[
p(B_0, B_p) \propto \left| \det(B_0) \right|^{\underline{\nu}} \exp \left( -\frac{1}{2} \left[ \operatorname{tr}((B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B})^T) \right] \right)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior Derivation
The posterior distribution is proportional to the product of the likelihood and the priors:
\[
p(B_0, B_p, \lambda \mid Y, X) \propto p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(B_0, B_p) p(\lambda)
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior for \(\lambda\)
Combining the likelihood and the prior for ():
\[
p(\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X) \propto \lambda^{-\frac{T}{2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right) \lambda^{-\underline{\nu}/2-1} \exp\left(-\frac{\underline{s}}{2\lambda}\right)
\]
Combining terms:
\[
p(\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X) \propto \lambda^{-\left(\frac{T}{2} + \frac{\underline{\nu}}{2} + 1\right)} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left(\sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \underline{s}\right)\right)
\]
This is recognized as the kernel of an Inverted-Gamma 2 distribution:
\[
\lambda \mid Y, B_0, B_p, X \sim \mathcal{IG2}\left(\underline{s} + \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) , \underline{\nu} + T \right)
\]
We use the results from the basic model (above) to compute the error terms that will be used in sampling \(\lambda\).

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Posterior for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\)
Considering the effect of \(\lambda\) on the residuals, the posterior parameters for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) should be adjusted accordingly. The presence of \(\lambda\) affects the variance in the likelihood, impacting the posterior distributions for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\).

Update Posterior Parameters
Taking \(\lambda\) into account, the posterior parameters for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) are:

Posterior for \(\bar{\Omega}\):

\[
\bar{\Omega} = \left(\frac{XX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{B}\):

\[
\bar{B} = \left(\frac{XX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \left(\frac{YX^T}{\lambda} + \underline{\Omega}^{-1}\underline{B}\right)
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{S}\):

\[
\bar{S} = \left( \frac{YY^T}{\lambda} + \underline{S}^{-1} + \underline{B}^{-1}\underline{B}^T - \bar{B}\bar{\Omega}\bar{B}^T \right)
\]

Posterior for \(\bar{\nu}\):

\[
\bar{\nu} = T + \underline{\nu}
\]

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Conclusion
We have re-derived the posteriors for the modified Bayesian SVAR model with the correct Inverted-Gamma 2 prior for \(\lambda\), where \(\lambda \sim \mathcal{IG2}(\underline{s}, \underline{\nu})\) with \(\underline{s} = \underline{\nu} - 2\). The correct derivation shows that \(\lambda\) scales the variance in the likelihood, impacting the posterior distributions of \(B_0\) and \(B_p\).
This approach highlights the importance of correctly handling matrix operations and applying Bayesian inference principles to a more complex model structure.

Second Extension: Estimating \(\nu\)
Following Lee (2022) we use a Metropolis-Hastings Algorithm to estimate \(\nu\) and impose a vmode value corresponding to the t-distribution range \((0, 25)\).


Conclusion
The overall kernel for this extended model encapsulates to the random variance \(\lambda\). This allows for a more robust handling of heteroscedasticity and potential non-stationarities in the error terms, offering nuanced insights into the dynamics under study.
In the basic model, all USD Index contemporaneous coefficients are not statistically significant at the standard levels. On the other hand, all these coefficients in the extended model are statistically significant at the 5% level.
The results suggest the following elasticities. According to the basic model, a weaker Dixie is likely to overheat the Australian economy: a drop of 1 per cent in the USD Index would result in roughly 1 per cent increase in inflation, roughly unchanged unemployment, and roughly 1% increase in the GDP growth rate.
On the other hand, the expanded model suggests that a weakening Dixie would result in an untraditional condition in the Australian economy: 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 0.7 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 1 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 1 per cent increase in the GDP growth rate.
As to the second extension, where \(\nu\) is a hyperparameter, this model suggests that a weakening Dixie would result in stagflation in Australia: 1 per cent decrease in the USD Index would result is roughly 3 per cent increase in inflation, roughly 0.7 per cent increase in unemployment, and roughly 3 per cent decrease in the GDP growth rate.

rgn_for_Extension_I_model = function(n,V,B0.initial){

   y   = Y
  
  # Basic settings and model dimensions
  N <- ncol(y)
  p <- 12   # This is the number of lags in the model
  K <- 1 + N * p

  # Set the priors
  kappa1 <- 0.01      # autoregressive slope shrinkage
  kappa2 <- 1         # constant term shrinkage 
  kappa3 <- 100       # contemporaneous effects shrinkage
  kappa4 <- 1         # VAR prior persistence
   

# create Y and X
############################################################
Y       = y[(p+1):nrow(y),]
X       = matrix(1,nrow(Y),1)
for (i in 1:p){
  X     = cbind(X,y[((p+1):nrow(y))-i,])
}

Y       = t(Y)
X       = t(X)
  
 
  priors <- list(
    B = cbind(rep(0, N), kappa4 * diag(N), matrix(0, N, (p - 1) * N)),
    Omega = diag(c(kappa2, kappa1 * ((1:p)^(-2)) %x% rep(1, N))),
    S = kappa3 * diag(N),
    nu = N
  )
  
   beta  = 5
  total = 0 
 
    A <- Y[ ,i]
    A <- matrix(A, ncol = 1)
    B <- X[ , i]
    B <- matrix(B, ncol = 1)
    C <- (B0_posterior1[ , , S]%*%A - Bp_posterior1[ , ,S]%*%B)
 
    partial_sum = t(C)%*%C
    total = total + partial_sum
  
  
  alpha = (beta - 2) + total
  
  N             = nrow(B0.initial)
  no.draws      = n
  
  B0            = array(NA, c(N,N,no.draws))
  B0.aux        = B0.initial
  
  for (i in 1:no.draws){
    
        # Sample lambda from the Inverse Gamma distribution

  lambda <- rinvgamma(n = 1, shape = alpha, rate = beta + nrow(y))
  
  lambda_posterior <- lambda

    # Compute posterior distribution parameters
  Omega.inv <- solve(priors$Omega)
  Omega.post.inv <-  ((lambda_posterior)^(-1) * X %*% t(X) +  Omega.inv)
  Omega.post <- solve(Omega.post.inv)
  B.post <-   ( (lambda_posterior)^(-1) * Y %*% t(X) +  priors$B %*% Omega.inv) %*% Omega.post
  S.post <-  solve( (lambda_posterior)^(-1) * Y %*% t(Y) +  solve(priors$S) + priors$B %*% Omega.inv %*% t(priors$B) - B.post %*% Omega.post.inv %*% t(B.post))
  nu.post <- nrow(y) + priors$nu
  
  posteriors <- list(
    B = B.post,
    Omega = Omega.post,
    S = S.post,
    nu = nu.post
  )

  S.inv = solve(S.post)
    
    for (n in 1:N){
      rn            = nrow(V[[n]])
      Un            = chol(nu*solve(V[[n]]%*%S.inv%*%t(V[[n]])))
      w             = t(orthogonal.complement.matrix.TW(t(B0.aux[-n,])))
      w1            = w %*% t(V[[n]]) %*% t(Un) / sqrt(as.numeric(w %*% t(V[[n]]) %*% t(Un) %*% Un %*% V[[n]] %*% t(w)))
      if (rn>1){
        Wn          = cbind(t(w1),orthogonal.complement.matrix.TW(t(w1)))
      } else {
        Wn          = w1
      }
      alpha         = rep(NA,rn)
      u             = rmvnorm(1,rep(0,nu+1),(1/nu)*diag(nu+1))
      alpha[1]      = sqrt(as.numeric(u%*%t(u)))
      if (runif(1)<0.5){
        alpha[1]    = -alpha[1]
      }
      if (rn>1){
        alpha[2:rn] = rmvnorm(1,rep(0,nrow(V[[n]])-1),(1/nu)*diag(rn-1))
      }
      bn            = alpha %*% Wn %*% Un
      B0.aux[n,]    = bn %*% V[[n]]
    }
    B0[,,i]         = B0.aux
  }
  
  return(B0)
}

title: Dixie Effect on Economic Stability in Australia
text:
Marginal Likelihood
First, we derive the marginal likelihood by integrating out \(\lambda\): \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, X) = \int p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(\lambda) \, d\lambda
\]
The likelihood and the prior for \(\lambda\) combine as: \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, \lambda, X) p(\lambda) \propto \lambda^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} + 1 \right)} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right) \right)
\]
Performing the integral: \[
\int_0^\infty \lambda^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} + 1 \right)} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\lambda} \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right) \right) d\lambda
\]
This integral is a standard form for the Inverted-Gamma distribution, yielding the marginal likelihood: \[
p(Y \mid B_0, B_p, X) \propto \left( \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) + \beta \right)^{-\left( \frac{T}{2} + \frac{\alpha}{2} \right)}
\]

Rewrite the likelihood term: \[
\exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} \sum_{t=1}^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t)^T (B_0 Y_t - B_p X_t) \right)
\]


Prior Contribution
The prior for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\) is: \[
\exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tr}((B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B})^T) \right)
\]

text:
Combining Terms
Combine the quadratic terms and complete the square to obtain the posterior distributions for \(B_0\) and \(B_p\): \[
-\frac{1}{2} \left( \operatorname{tr}((Y - B_0^{-1}B_p X)^T B_0^T B_0 (Y - B_0^{-1}B_p X)) + \operatorname{tr}((B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B})^T) \right)
\]
Recognize the combined quadratic form: \[
-\frac{1}{2} \left( (B_0 Y - B_p X)^T B_0^T B_0 (B_0 Y - B_p X) + (B_0 - \underline{B}) \underline{\Omega}^{-1} (B_0 - \underline{B}) \right)
\]
